com.versant.util
Class CppList

java.lang.Object
  com.versant.trans.SCO
      com.versant.util.CppList
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
public class CppList
extends SCO
implements java.lang.Cloneable, java.io.Serializable

This is a Second Class Object to be used only as an attribute in a persistent instance of a C++ defined class when you want to share objects and classes created from the VERSANT C++ language interface with the transparent Java binding.

This class is based on the LinkedList class in the java.util package of JDK 1.2

The CppList has precise control over where in the CppList each element is inserted. You can access elements by their integer index (position) in the CppList, and search for elements in the CppList.

Unlike sets, CppLists typically allow duplicate elements. More formally, CppLists typically allow pairs of elements e1 and e2 such that e1.equals(e2).

CppLists provide four methods for positional (indexed) access to list elements. CppLists (like Java arrays) are zero based. Note that these operations execute in time proportional to the index value. Thus, iterating over the elements in a CppList is preferable to indexing through it.

CppList provides a special Iterator, called a CppListIterator. It allows element insertion and replacement, and bi-directional access to the normal Iterator operations. A method is provided to obtain a CppListIterator that starts at a specified position in the List.

CppList provides four methods to search for a specified object. From a performance standpoint, these you should use these methods with caution.

CppList provides two methods to efficiently insert and remove multiple elements at an arbitrary point in the list.

CppList provides uniformly named methods to get, remove, and insert an element at the beginning and end of the List. These operations allow the CppList to be used as a stack, queue, or double-ended queue (deque).

All of the stack/queue/deque operations could be easily recast in terms of the standard CppList operations.

All of the operations perform as could be expected for a doubly linked list. Operations that index into the list will traverse the list from the beginning or the end, whichever is closer to the specified index.

Note that this implementation is not synchronized.

If multiple threads access a CppList concurrently, and at least one of the threads modifies the CppList structurally, it must be synchronized externally. (A structural modification is any operation that adds or deletes one or more elements; merely setting the value of an element is not a structural modification.) This is typically accomplished by synchronizing on some object that naturally encapsulates the CppList.

The Iterators returned by CppList's iterator and listIterator() methods are fail-fast: if the CppList is structurally modified at any time after the Iterator is created, except through the Iterator's own remove or add methods, the Iterator throws a RuntimeException. Thus, in the face of concurrent modification, the Iterator fails quickly and cleanly, rather than risking arbitrary, non-deterministic behavior at an undetermined time in the future.

See Also:
CppListIterator, Serialized Form

listIterator

public CppListIterator listIterator(int index)
Gets an iterator pointing to a position. The CppListIterator is fail-fast. If this List is structurally modified at any time after the creation of the CppListIterator, or in any way except through the CppListIterator's own remove or add methods, the CppListIterator throws a RuntimeException. Thus, in concurrent modification, the CppListIterator fails quickly and cleanly, rather than risking arbitrary, non-deterministic behavior later.

Parameters:
index - Index of first element to be returned from the CppListIterator (by a call to getNext).
Returns:
CppListIterator() of the elements in this List (in proper sequence), starting at the specified position in the list.
Throws:
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index is out of range (index < 0 || index > size()).
See Also:
CppListIterator

isEmpty

public boolean isEmpty()
Return the current status of the list.

Returns:
True if this List contains no elements. This implementation returns size() == 0.

contains

public boolean contains(java.lang.Object o)
Checks elements for equality.

Parameters:
o - The object to find. This method iterates over the elements in the List checking each element in turn for equality with o.
Returns:
true if this List contains the specified element. More formally, returns true if and only if this List contains at least one element e such that (o == null ? e == null : o.equals(e)).

toArray

public java.lang.Object[] toArray()
Create a new array that contains this list.

This method allocates the array to be returned and iterates over the elements in the List. It stores each object reference in the next consecutive element of the array, starting with element 0.

This method returns an array containing all of the elements in this List.

If the List makes any guarantees, as to what order its iterator returns its elements, this method must return the elements in the same order.

The returned array will be "safe". No references to it are maintained by the List. In other words, this method must allocate a new array even if the List is backed by an Array. You are thus free to modify the returned array.

public boolean add(java.lang.Object o)
Appends the specified element to the end of this List (optional operation). This implementation calls add(size(),obj).

Parameters:
o - Element to be appended to this List.
Returns:
True if add is successful.

ClassCastExceptionif - the class of the specified element prevents it from being added to this Set.

remove

public boolean remove(java.lang.Object o)
Removes an element.

Parameters:
o - Element to be removed from this List, if present.

This method removes a single instance of the specified element from this List, if it is present (optional operation). This implementation iterates over the List looking for the specified element. If it finds the element, it removes the element from the List using the iterator's remove method.

Returns:
true if the List contained the specified element or equivalently, if the List changed as a result of the call.

addAll

public boolean addAll(CppList c)
Adds elements. This method adds all of the elements in the specified List to this List (optional operation).

The behavior of this operation is undefined if the specified List is modified while the operation is in progress. (This implies that the behavior of this call is undefined if the specified List is this List, and this List is nonempty.)

This implementation iterates over the specified List, and adds each object returned by the CppListIterator() to this List.

Parameters:
c - The List whose elements you want to add to this List.
See Also:
CppList.add(Object)

containsAll

public boolean containsAll(CppList c)
Returns true if this List contains all of the elements in the specified List.

This implementation iterates over the specified List and checks each element returned by the CppListIterator to see if it is contained in this List. If all elements are true is returned; otherwise, false.

Parameters:
c - The List whose elements you want to check with this List.
See Also:
CppList.contains(Object)

removeAll

public boolean removeAll(CppList c)
Removes list of elements. This method removes from this List all of its elements that are contained in the specified List (optional operation).

This implementation iterates over this List and checks each element returned by the CppListIterator()to see if it is contained in the specified List. If it is contained, it is removed from this List with the CppListIterator's remove method.

Parameters:
c - The List whose elements you want to remove from this List.

Returns:
true if this List changed as a result of the call.

See Also:
CppList.remove(int), CppList.contains(Object)

retainAll

public boolean retainAll(CppList c)
Retains only the elements in this CppList that are contained in the specified CppList (optional operation). This method removes from this CppList all of its elements that are not contained in the specified CppList. This implementation iterates over this CppList, checking each element returned by the CppListIterator in turn to see if it is contained in the specified CppList. If it is not so contained, it is removed from this CppList with the CppListIterator's remove method.

Parameters:
c - The List whose elements you want to remove from this List.
Returns:
true if this CppList changed as a result of the call.
See Also:
CppList.remove(int), CppList.contains(Object)

get

public java.lang.Object get(int index)
Returns the element at the specified position in this List. This implementation first gets a CppListIterator() that points to the indexed element (with listIterator(index)); then, it gets the element using CppListIterator.next and returns it.

Parameters:
index - The index of element to return.
Throws:
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException() - if index is out of range (index < 0 || index >= size()).

set

public java.lang.Object set(int index,
                            java.lang.Object element)
Replaces the element at the specified position in this List with the specified element. This implementation first gets a CppListIterator() that points to the indexed element (with listIterator(index)). Then, it gets the current element using CppListIterator.next and replaces it with CppListIterator.set.

Parameters:
index - Index of element to replace.
element - Element to be stored at the specified position.
Returns:
The element previously at the specified position.
Throws:
NullPointerException - if this List does not permit null elements; one of the elements of c is null.
ClassCastException - if the class of the specified element prevents it from being added to this List.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if some aspect of the specified element prevents it from being added to this List.
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index is out of range (index < 0 || index >= size()).
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if fromIndex() > toIndex().

add

public void add(int index,
                java.lang.Object element)
Add an element. This method inserts the specified element at the specified position in this List, and shifts the element currently at that position (if any) and any subsequent elements to the right (adds one to their indexes).

This implementation first gets a CppListIterator that points to the indexed element (with CppListIterator(index)). Then, it inserts the specified element with CppListIterator.add.

Parameters:
index - Index at which the specified element is to be inserted.
element - Element to be inserted.
Throws:
NullPointerException - if this List does not permit null elements; one of the elements of c is null.
ClassCastException - if class of the specified element prevents it from being added to this List.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if some aspect of the specified element prevents it from being added to this List.
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if index is out of range (index < 0 || index > size()).

                       int index)
Gets an element by iterating backwards. This method gets a CppListIterator pointing to the element after the indexed element (with cppListIterator(index)) and then iterates backwards over the list until the specified element is found, or the beginning of the list is reached.

Parameters:
o - Element to be searched.
index - Initial position to search for the specified element.
Returns:

java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if index out of range (index < 0 || index >= size()).

removeRange

public void removeRange(int fromIndex,
                        int toIndex)
Removes from this List all of the elements whose index is between fromIndex, inclusive and toIndex, exclusive. This method shifts any succeeding elements to the left (reduces their index). This call shortens the List by (toIndex() - fromIndex()) elements. (If toIndex == fromIndex, this operation has no effect.)

This implementation first checks to see that the indexes are in range. Then, it gets a CppListIterator that points to the element at the beginning of the range (with cppListIterator(index)). Finally, it iterates over the range, calling CppListIterator's remove operation for each element to be removed.

Parameters:
fromIndex - Index of first element to be removed.
toIndex - Index after last element to be removed.
Throws:
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if fromIndex() or toIndex() out of range (fromIndex < 0 || fromIndex >= size() || toIndex > size() || toIndex < fromIndex ).

addAll

public boolean addAll(int index,
                      CppList c)
Adds elements. This method inserts all of the elements in the specified List into this List at the specified position (optional operation); and shifts the element currently at that position (if any) and any subsequent elements to the right (increases their indexes).

The new elements appear in the List in the order that they are returned by the specified Lists' iterator. The behavior of this operation is unspecified if the specified List is modified while the operation is in progress. (Note that this behavior will occur if the specified List is this List, and it is not empty.)

This implementation gets an CppListIterator over the specified List and iterates over it. It inserts the elements from the CppListIterator into this List at the appropriate position one at a time, using add(int, Object). Many implementations will override this method for efficiency.

Parameters:
index - Index at which to insert first element from the specified List
c - Elements to be inserted into this List.
Returns:
True if this List changed as a result of the call.
Throws:
ClassCastException - if class of one of the elements of the specified List that prevents it from being added to this List.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if some aspect of one of elements of the specified List that prevents it from being added to this List.
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if index out of range (index < 0 || index > size()).

iterator

public CppListIterator iterator()
Returns a CppListIterator over the elements in this List in proper sequence.

Returns:
Straightforward implementation of the CppListIterator interface, relying on the backing List's size(), get(int), and remove(int) methods.

Throws:
java.lang.Runtime - exceptions in the face of concurrent modification

cppListIterator

public CppListIterator cppListIterator()
Returns an CppListIterator of the elements in this List (in proper sequence). This implementation returns cppListIterator(0).

See Also:
CppList.cppListIterator(int)

cppListIterator

public CppListIterator cppListIterator(int index)
Gets list iterator. This method returns a CppListIterator of the elements in this List (in proper sequence) that starts at the specified position in the List.

The specified index indicates the first element that would be returned by an initial call to nextElement(). An initial call to previousElement() would return the element with the specified index minus one.

This implementation returns a straightforward implementation of the CppListIterator interface. The CppListIterator implementation relies on the backing List's get(int), set(int, Object), add(int, Object) and remove(int) methods.

Note that the CppListIterator returned by this implementation will throw an UnsupportedOperationException() in response to its remove, set and add methods, unless the List's remove(int), set(int, Object), and add(int, Object) methods are overridden (respectively).

Parameters:
index - Index of first element to be returned from the CppListIterator() (by a call to getNext).
Throws:
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if index is out of range (index < 0 || index >size()).

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object o)
Compares the specified object with this List for equality. This method returns true if and only if the specified Object is also a List, if both Lists have the same size, and if all corresponding pairs of elements in the two Lists are equal. (Two elements, e1 and e2, are equal if (e1 == null ? e2 == null : e1.equals(e2)).) In other words, two Lists are defined to be equal if they contain the same elements in the same order.

This implementation first checks if the specified object is this List. If so, it returns true; if not, it checks if the specified object is a List. If not, it returns false; if so, it iterates over both lists, comparing corresponding pairs of elements. If any comparison returns false, this method returns false. If either CppListIterator runs out of elements before the other, it returns false (as the Lists are of unequal length); otherwise, it returns true when the iterations complete.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
o - The object to be compared for equality with this List.
Returns:
true if the specified Object is equal to this List.

hashCode

public int hashCode()
Returns the hash code value for this List.

This implementation uses exactly the code that defines the List hash function in the documentation for List.hashCode.

Overrides:
hashCode in class java.lang.Object

clone

public java.lang.Object clone()
